Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Simultaneous Broadband and Highly Efficient Wireless Powering and Communication of Wearable Wireless Sensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will go beyond wearable sensors. This project is expected to yield significant societal benefits on health and quality of life, as the proposed technology will be able to support the safe powering and communication of novel wireless systems that will enable next generation applications; including, implantable or wearable biomonitoring of senior people in assisted living, pacemakers, drug delivery, artificial organs, bionics for people with disabilities and injured military personnel, and novel treatments for cancer and brain disorders. This project is also expected to revolutionize other commercial applications, such as, wireless sensors for structural health monitoring and environmental monitoring. In addition, this project is expected to broaden broadening the participation of underrepresented groups through Senior Design projects on wireless powering and outreach efforts.

This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project will generate the required technological knowledge for deriving the first miniaturized wireless power transfer systems, which can simultaneously and safely transmit power to and communicate with wearable devices and sensors, with unprecedented power transfer efficiency, bandwidth and alignment-insensitive characteristics. Therefore, this project is expected to have a significant impact on the development of new and/or conformal wearable battery-less devices that support novel biomonitoring, diagnostic techniques and therapies and enhancing our capabilities for disease prevention and treatment. This project is also expected to lead to the first generation of truly autonomous wireless implantable devices for various applications such as smart medicine activation, artificial organ enhanced performance and status monitoring.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project generated the required technological knowledge that led to the development of miniaturized and highly efficient wireless power transfer systems, which simultaneously and safely transmit power to and communicate with wearable devices and sensors. This technology eliminates wires that supply power to wearable devices thereby enabling the development of new wearable devices that receive their power and transmit/receive their data wirelessly. Therefore, our technology enables the development of future wireless wearable devices that support novel biomonitoring, diagnostic techniques and therapies and enhancing our capabilities for disease prevention and treatment. The performance of this technology was thoroughly characterized and validated by measurements of prototyped systems.

The outcomes of our research are expected to yield significant societal benefits because of their impact to health and quality of life, as they support the safe powering and communication of novel wireless systems that will enable next generation applications; including, implantable or wearable biomonitoring of senior people in assisted living, pacemakers, drug delivery, artificial organs, bionics for people with disabilities and injured military personnel, and novel treatments for cancer and brain disorders. It is also expected that our work will revolutionize other applications, such as, wireless sensors for structural health monitoring and environmental monitoring.


Last Modified: 10/10/2016
Modified by: Argy Petros

Therefore, our technology enables the development of future wireless wearable devices that support novel biomonitoring, diagnostic techniques and therapies and enhancing our capabilities for disease prevention and treatment. The performance of this technology was thoroughly characterized and validated by measurements of prototyped systems. The outcomes of our research are expected to yield significant societal benefits because of their impact to health and quality of life, as they support the safe powering and communication of novel wireless systems that will enable next generation applications; including, implantable or wearable biomonitoring of senior people in assisted living, pacemakers, drug delivery, artificial organs, bionics for people with disabilities and injured military personnel, and novel treatments for cancer and brain disorders.
